ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Writing leadership journals, engaging in discourse on current leadership topics
Got to discuss current events and apply different thinking to them as well as our lives. Good presentation practice.
I learned about different topics within the Air Force framework for leadership and communication

ability to assess Air Force structures, organizations, and positions of power with a constructive eye
better understanding of the geopolitical role America has in current times
deep understanding of leadership visions, missions, and philosophies, including on a personal level
Had in-depth discussions regarding topics relevant to Air Force leadership.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: awesome discussion periods! 

Weakness: poor communication on assignment requirements

The daily discourse was nice when it was about current events. When it was about random thought leaders or pick your own leader it kinda fell apart. The lecture portion didn't seem to really cover much as it was presented by the students. I didn't get much from the lectures, most of the info came from the student readers which many times don't actually have information in them as they expect the topic to be taught via lecture.

I really enjoyed the daily discourses and guest speakers. I thought our class discussions allowed us to make use of the Air Force curriculum in a way that is actually meaningful - which is not how I have felt about all AF classes. Perhaps a little more time doing things like case studies would be good.
The strengths of this course lie in the many great discussions we had, whether it was daily discourse or sharing our personal experiences, the conversations were always intellectually stimulating.

Strengths: 
the best AS course so far; very flexible and engaging, creative and informal; covers a lot of ground, and Maj Moen incorporates engaging and dynamic material into the course for an enhanced learning experience
Weaknesses: 
clearer expectations with the first and second assignments (fixed for 3rd and 4th though)

Strengths include that it was much different from previous AS classes and I actually learned quite a bit of real-world insight and going-ons as well as how that connected to Air Force values and goals. However, a possible weakness is that, especially because this class is not even considered a credit at Yale, there was more work than I think it necessarily entails. Often, I spent more time on this class than I did in my other classes. While I learned so much more this semester, it also became a point of stress for a little bit. I think in the future clearly state that this class will be much more work and/or reduce the amount of outside-of-class assignments that are required each week.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A war movie would have been fun to watch over zoom together and analyze!
Breaks were nice and pretty necessary as its hard to focus on zoom early in the morning for hours on end.
I thought it was well run.
All of them succeeded. I wish it was easier to organize smaller group discussions, but tis is Zoom.
engaging daily discourses, discussion on meaningful disagreement, flexible with deadlines/assignments

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If they are in ROTC, yes
If you are in ROTC you have to take it.
It is required for AFROTC cadets.

I was thoroughly surprised by this course. Maj Moen really took a new direction with the courseload and content, making it (in my opinion) the level of an actual yale course. the content covered is engaging; the papers are meaningful, reflective, and useful; and I felt very engaged with my peers in the class. Highly rec!
